I am writing to plead for your attention to recent protests in Hong Kong against the Fugitive Offenders and Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation (Amendment) Bill 2019 (“extradition bill”), and launch an investigation into the abuse of power by the Hong Kong Police Force in recent days, especially on 11 August 2019.

Anti-extradition bill protest
For weeks, Hong Kong people have been protesting peacefully against the extradition bill, demanding an official response from the HKSAR government to the five major demands:
(1) a complete withdrawal of extradition bill;
(2) a retraction of the "riot" characterization;
(3) a retraction of charges against anti-extradition protestors;
(4) the establishment of an independent commission of inquiry into police conduct and use of force during protests;
(5) the implementation of universal suffrage for Legislative Council and Chief Executive elections.

However, as of right now, none of these demands have been met by the Hong Kong government. Although Carrie Lam, the HKSAR Chief Executive, claimed that "the bill is dead" on 9 July, the bill is still listed on latest official gazette. It is obvious that the bill is not yet fully withdrawn. In a press conference on 9 August, Carrie Lam refused to take any concrete actions to relieve the tensions, nor did she suggest any solutions to address the political conflicts and turmoil. She also characterized the protesters as having “no stake in society", ignoring the protests held by and letters from different professional and non-professional organizations and social categories. Instead, more and more evidence seems to suggest that, with the support of Beijing, the Hong Kong government had decided to carry out a brutal crackdown with the help of police, triad gangs and mercenaries from China. On 12 August, the Chinese government described the recent protests in Hong Kong as terrorism. The tough attitude of the Beijing government and the arrogance of the Hong Kong Chief Executive could lead to a recurrence of the "June-Fourth massacre" in Hong Kong.

Abuse of Power by Hong Kong Police Force
Amnesty International has conducted a report to investigate the use of force by the police, concluding that unnecessary and excessive force was indeed used by Hong Kong Police Force against the peaceful and unarmed protestors and journalists, including (but not limited to) tear gas, pepper spray, rubber bullets and baton charges. Yet, people's demand of an independent investigation of the abuse of power by the police has been turned down by the Chief Executive, with her assuring her support for the police on 27 June. Moreover, such an abuse is getting more violent, especially in the protests on 11 August.

I sincerely plead for the investigation on force abuse by Hong Kong Police, and your urging the Chinese government and Hong Kong government to answer Hong Kong people's five demands.
